did.abstract: The Gil J Wolman papers consists of correspondence, writings, printed items, artworks, photographs, sound recordings, and other materials by or relating to French artist Gil J Wolman (1929-1995) and his milieu. The collection documents the early Lettrist movement of the 1950s through correspondence, writings of Wolman and others, and materials related to Lettrist films, especially Wolman's Anticoncept (1952) and Isidore Isou's Traité de bave et d'éternité (1951). The collection also documents the creation of Wolman's artist's books, literary works, and sound poetry ("mégapneumie"), as well as his professional career in the Paris art gallery scene from circa 1960 to 1995. Correspondents include Noël Arnaud, Serge Berna, Jean Louis Brau, Guy Debord, François Dufrêne, Isidore Isou, Maurice Lemaître, Dominique

langmaterial.language: Chiefly in French, with some material in English, German, and Italian.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Charlotte Wolman, Hedy Laure Wolman, and Didier Lecointre-Dominique Drouet on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2012.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into nine series: I. Correspondence, 1946-2004. II. Lettrist Movement Material, 1946-1992. III. Writings, 1950-1995. IV. L'Anticoncept Film Files, 1951-2000. V. Professional Papers, 1952-2008. VI. Artworks, 1965-1992. VII. Audio Recordings, 1965-2010. VIII. Writings about Wolman, 1974-2011. IX. Personal Papers, 1937-1995.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Joseph Wolman (1929-1995), best known by the name Gil J Wolman, was a French artist whose work spanned the visual arts, poetry, sound poetry, and filmmaking. Closely associated with the Lettrist movement, Wolman was among the founding members of the Internationale lettriste.

Born in 1929 in Paris, Wolman spent part of his youth working in wool clothing manufacture, and as a journalist. In 1950, along with Maurice Lemaître, Jean Louis Brau, Serge Berna, and Guy Debord, Wolman joined the young Lettrist movement led by Isidore Isou since 1945. Other figures of significance to the Lettrist movement's evolution from the 1940s to the 1960s include Gabriel Pomerand, François Dufrêne, Jacques Spacagna, and Roberto Altmann.

The years following Wolman's integration to the movement witnessed a period of collaboration among the Lettrists, the production of experimental films, and the publication of several magazines. In 1952, internal disagreements led to the creation of the break-off group Internationale lettriste by Debord, Wolman, Berna, and Brau. This new, radical Lettrism in turn influenced other European avant-garde groups interested in the intersections of art, politics, and society, such as the International Movement for an Imaginist Bauhaus (founded by Asger Jorn, Giuseppe Pinot-Gallizio, and Piero Simondo in 1955 in Italy), the Internationale situationniste (a collective led by Debord created in 1957), and Gruppe Spur (a German collective active from 1957-1965). Excluded from the Internationale lettriste in 1957, Wolman founded the Deuxième internationale lettriste in 1963 with Brau and Dufrêne.

Wolman's contributions to Lettrism are numerous, and include the invention of mégapneumes in the early 1950s (sound poems articulated solely with breath), and the production of content for several publications ( Internationale lettriste , Deuxième internationale lettriste , Potlatch , Ion , etc). Wolman was also involved in Lettrist experimental cinema, not only through his own film L'Anticoncept (1951), but also appearing on the soundtrack of Isou's Traité de bave et d'éternité (1950-51) and Debord's Hurlements en faveur de Sade (1951). Finally, Wolman theorized the technique of "détournement" with Debord in 1956, a technique that would become central to both Debord's Situationist writings, and Wolman's future artistic practices.

From the 1960s onwards, Wolman actively participated in the Paris art gallery scene. In 1963, he invented "art scotch", politically subversive collages of newspaper content extracted from their original pages with translucent adhesive tape. In the 1970s and 1980s, Wolman experimented with photocopy art and the making of artists' books, and developed the "mouvement séparatiste" (the disruptive insertion of blank spaces in his artworks and texts). In addition to exhibiting in numerous solo and collective shows, Wolman served as editor of the exhibition directory L'Officiel des galeries . Starting circa 1979, Wolman self-published small runs of poetry and art books through his "Éditions inconnues" (Unknown editions).
Wolman met his life partner, artist and writer Charlotte Wolman (née Mandel), at a Lettrist recital in 1958. He passed away on July 3, 1995.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Gil J Wolman Papers. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections as they are acquired, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.
These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards. For more information, please refer to the Beinecke Manuscript Unit Processing Manual.
In 2017, this collection was processed at a basic level, which included rehousing and minimal organization while maintaining the box order in which the collection was originally received.

Full processing of the collection was completed in 2018. Contents of the folders were verified against the dealer inventory and the original box labels (largely in Charlotte Wolman's hand); materials were sorted within and across boxes; and description at the file level was provided.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Gil J Wolman Papers consists of correspondence, writings, printed material, artworks, photographs, audio recordings, and other materials by or relating to French artist Gil J Wolman (1929-1995) and his milieu. The collection documents the early Lettrist movement through correspondence, writings of Wolman and others, and material related to Lettrist films, especially Wolman's L'Anticoncept and Isidore Isou's Traité de bave et d'éternité . Correspondents include Noël Arnaud, Serge Berna, Jean Louis Brau, Guy Debord, François Dufrêne, Isidore Isou, Maurice Lemaître, Dominique Meens, and others. Of note are preparatory material for the Internationale lettriste periodical and mégapneumie notations, as well as Lettrist poems, screenplays, and theoretical texts in manuscript or typescript authored and annotated by the movement's leading figures, especially by Debord, Isou, Brau, and Dufrêne. The collection also holds the unpublished last pages of Guy Debord's "Manifeste pour une construction des situations" (1953).

Additionally, the collection documents Wolman's literary works, sound poetry, and professional career in the Paris gallery scene. Drafts, printing tests, and visuals for Wolman's artists' books created from the mid-1970s to the early 1990s constitute a large part of the collection, and feature, among others, Dühring, Dühring (1979), L'homme séparé (1979), Wolman résumé des chapitres précédents (1981), Les inhumations: suivi de Peinture dépeinte (1995). Evidence of Wolman's artistic production include exhibition catalogs, invitation cards, administrative records, and a small number of original artworks, including an art scotch canvas and prints.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Gil J Wolman Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The rare instances of letters composed by Wolman are filed in the alphabetical sequence when the recipient's significance warranted name access (see Berlé, Pierre-Joel), or when exchanges are present (see Centre national de la cinématographie). Otherwise, they were filed under "Wolman, Gil J. Outgoing correspondence".

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Correspondence on the preparation of exhibitions can also be found among administrative documents in Series V. Professional Papers. Mail art can also be found in Series VI. Artworks, with other items gathered by Wolman as source material for collages and copy art.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I. comprises incoming correspondence, largely of a professional nature, from artists, writers, gallery administrators, book sellers, scholars, and friends. Rich correspondence from Guy Debord, Maurice Lemaître, Serge Berna, and Jean Louis Brau offers a view into the Lettrist movement of the early 1950s: the internal politics of their membership, their relations with the French authorities, the creation of their magazines, and their theories about art, politics, and society. A smaller number of letters dating from the 1960s-1970s by other significant avant-garde figures in Wolman's milieu is also extant, including from Isidore Isou, Henri Chopin, Noël Arnaud, François Dufrêne, and Roberto Altmann. Letters from administrators of cultural institutions in Europe and the United States discuss the planning of exhibitions or film screenings featuring works by Wolman. Also of note is extensive correspondence from poet and author Dominique Meens accompanied by drafts of his writings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains typed circular letters sent to members of Lemaître's Lettrist circle discussing the publications of Lettrist magazines, particularly Nouvelle génération , collaborative exhibitions, disagreements with Isou, and the internal politics of the Lettrist movement. Most letters are by Lemaître, but the grouping also includes a small number of responses from Jean Louis Brau, Jacques Spacagna, and Pierre Descamps.
Also contains letters addressed to Wolman only. Enclosed in letter postmarked 1962 June 09 are four Ektachrome transparencies of artworks in a gallery.

Poems and texts enclosed in the correspondence include typescripts of "De l'interruption du dire" (1986), "Scolastique de l'être" (1988), and "Porc" (1990); and typed drafts of Ornithologie du promeneur (1991) with corrections by Wolman. Also enclosed is a copy of La trajectoire du figurant by Philippe Joseph Meens (undated).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II. documents the evolution of Lettrism in France in the 1950s and 1960s through original texts, publications, ephemera, and internal documents collected by Wolman. The series comprises Lettrist poems, screenplays, and theoretical texts in manuscript or typescript authored by the movement's leading figures, and sometimes annotated by other group members. Including writings by Guy Debord, Jean Louis Brau, Serge Berna, François Dufrêne, Isidore Isou, and others, the series illustrates a period of collaboration amongst figures who would later disassociate. Of note is the unpublished last pages of Guy Debord's "Manifeste pour une construction des situations," dated 1953 September 21, and long thought to be lost.

The series also contains literary and theoretical magazines, including a complete run of the Internationale lettriste's newsletter Potlatch (1954-1959); tracts and other printed ephemera; and internal documents like account books and notes regarding the publication of Lettrist magazines. Beyond Lettrist material, the series also includes a few publications from related avant-garde groups such as the Internationale situationniste and the Mouvement international pour un Bauhaus imaginiste.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: For writings by Wolman on mégapneumie, "art integral," Debord's developing situationist theories, and other early Lettrist notes, see Series III. Writings, Subseries. Early Lettrist Writings. For screenplay drafts of Wolman's Lettrist film L'Anticoncept , see Series IV., Box 38, Folders 522-531.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: Collected Writings, Publication and Ephemera, and Internal Documents.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III. documents Wolman's literary works, from the theoretical writings about mégapneumie of his early Lettrist years, to his production of books from the late 1970s to the early 1990s. The bulk of the series consists of drafts, background material, visuals, and printing tests for Wolman's anthology Wolman résumé des chapitres précédents (1981), his artists' books, such as Dühring, Dühring (1979), and his poetic texts, especially Les inhumations: suivi de Peinture dépeinte (1995). Other writings include poems, theoretical notes relating to Lettrism, notations for mégapneumes, and unidentified manuscripts.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four subseries: Books, Short Works, Early Lettrist Writings, and Notes and Untitled Manuscripts.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: For L'Anticoncept screenplay, see Series IV.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The subseries evidences Wolman's process for constructing books. Wolman's bookmaking intersected with his visual arts practices, particularly that of détournement through textual appropriation and photocopy art. Wolman utilized newspaper clippings, drawings, and appropriated or original texts and photographs, combined through collage and photocopy. For example, Dühring Dühring ([Paris]: Éditions inconnues, 1979) consists of nouns selected from Friedrich Engels's book Anti-Dühring placed atop drawings and photographs of human faces. Several books, such as L'homme séparé (1979), Dühring Dühring (1979), Haute vie (1987), were elaborated concurrently with a gallery installation featuring enlarged prints from the book's content.

In addition to drafts and proofs, the subseries also contains reference materials gathered by Wolman in preparation for his retrospective book Wolman résumé des chapitres précédants (1981), and for a prospective sequel, organized in chronological folders. These largely include ephemera from exhibitions and festivals, and newspaper clippings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV. contains screenplay drafts, essays, invoices, ephemera, clippings, and other materials related to Wolman's experimental film L'Anticoncept . A landmark of Lettrist cinema created in 1951, the film solely consists of a sound track narrated by Wolman and images of white circles projected on a balloon. After its first screening in February 1952 in Paris, the film was censored by the French authorities in April 1952, and showed only to journalists at the 1952 Cannes Film Festival. Materials in Series IV. date from the film's original conception and screenings in the early 1950s, and from the 1980s-1990s, documenting a resurgence of interest in screening Wolman's work as part of avant-garde cinema retrospectives.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Most items in Series IV. were found in two envelopes. Material from other containers were transfered to this series when directly related to these envelope groupings.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: See Series I. for correspondence from cultural institutions and production companies regarding L'Anticoncept . See Series VII., Box 52, Folder 690 for the film's sound track on phonograph record.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four subseries: Administrative Documents, Exhibition and Trade Publications, Ephemera, and Editorial Work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series V. documents Wolman's presence in the Paris art scene from the 1960s to the 1990s through his gallery shows, his participation to collective exhibitions, art fairs, and festivals, and his editorial work for the directory L'Officiel des galleries . The series also illustrates interest in Wolman's work outside of Paris by a few cultural institutions across France, Europe, and North America. Administrative documents in the series largely relate to exhibition preparation, and include loan receipts, forms, and project proposals. Publications and printed ephemera include catalogs from museum exhibitions, gallery shows, art fairs, and auction sales featuring Wolman's art or other artists in his network; and invitation cards, posters, and flyers advertising his gallery shows. The series also includes a small group of material relating to Wolman's editorial work for three cultural magazines published in Paris: L'Entracte , L'Officiel des antiquaries , and L'Officiel des galleries .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains project descriptions, forms, and calls for public participation in creating Wolman's F.I.A.C. installations. Includes typescripts for "Projet pour le PIAC (Parking International d'Art Contemporain)" (1977) and "Dispersion de la collection Wolman" [circa 1982]; a press release and delivery forms for the installation of fax machines for "Je vous envoie un dessin" (1984); a call for photograph submissions for "L'autre moitié" (1986); and holograph price list for several artists (1987). Accompanied by the tract "Intervention no. 2 L'oreille de Van Gogh" (1974) by Henri J. Enu for the 1975 F.I.A.C.

processinfo.head: Processing Information

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: Works by Gil J Wolman, and Works by Others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series VI. largely consists of artwork by Wolman in the form of prints, photocopies, photographs, portfolios, drawings, and an original canvas. It offers limited documentation of the concepts and media explored by Wolman in his visual art from the 1960s to the 1980s, including "art scotch", copy art, and "séparation". The series also includes a small number of drawings, prints, and other artworks by other artists in Wolman's milieu.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Box 67: Restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 24 x 35 cm on canvas. When creating his "art scotch", Wolman used tape to lift ink off newspaper or magazine pages, and remixed the printed words or images extracted with the tape on a new support, here a canvas.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two composite negatives made of cellophane pressure-sensitive tape pieces placed between acetate sheets, used by Wolman to print posters advertising his art scotch. One features text and headlines transferred from newspapers, and appears as the background to the poster for Galerie Valerie Schmidt, Art Scotch 2: faux témoignages de Wolman (1966). The other features images of eyes and mouths, likely transferred from magazines, over blocks of text. 24 x 21 cm each. Both exhibit signs of degradation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two copies, caption: "Freud de Gauvin, séparation de Wolman, autobuste de Clavel".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Three series, composed of overlapping press clippings, of a woman's portrait, and of manuscript notes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fourteen posters, presumably printed by Wolman, for the Festival de Fort Boyard (June 1967), an imaginary avant-garde art festival conceptualized by Wolman, Henri Chopin, Antonio Berni, Gianni Bertini, Julien Blaine, and others. Contains unique printings with varying colors and details of 4 posters featuring artworks by different artists: 9 printings featuring Blaine (including one printed on L'Humanité newspaper issue, dated 1967 June 10, front only); 1 printing featuring Bertini; 1 printing featuring Milos Urbasek; 3 printings featuring an unsigned artwork.
